qualitative_insights.main_objective: To develop a cost-effective Ca-enriched biochar from sheep manure and oyster shell waste for efficient phosphate adsorption in aqueous solutions.
qualitative_insights.key_methodology_summary: Pyrolysis of sheep manure at 500°C under N₂ atmosphere, followed by Ca-modification using HCl-treated oyster shell solution. Characterization included SEM-EDS, FTIR, XRD, and adsorption experiments with Langmuir/Freundlich/Sips model fitting.
primary_findings_conclusions: Maximum phosphate adsorption capacity of 146.28 mg P/g (Langmuir model)
Adsorption mechanism dominated by Ca²⁺-PO₄³⁻ complexation forming hydroxyapatite
94% adsorption efficiency at 50 mg P/L concentration
Adsorption capacity increased with pH (89.5-93.3 mg P/g at pH >7)
Ca content in biochar positively correlated with adsorption performance
limitations_discussed_by_authors: Reduced adsorption efficiency under acidic conditions (pH <7)
Interference from NO₃⁻ and SO₄²⁻ anions reduced adsorption by 3.72-2.79%
Lower surface area (4.74 m²/g) compared to other Ca-modified biochars
qualitative_insights.novelty_significance_claim: First demonstration of simultaneous valorization of sheep manure and oyster shell waste to create high-performance adsorbent, addressing both agricultural waste management and water pollution challenges.
qualitative_insights.key_tables_figures_present: Table 4 (comparison of Ca-modified biochar adsorption capacities), Figures 1-2 (SEM-EDS of biochar), Figure 5 (adsorption isotherms/kinetics), Figure 6 (pH/anion effects)
